What happened since then is that Brush trading went a bit wrong, forcing deeper cost cuts than initially expected.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

But that gets ahead of ourselves. Let's recap the detail here.

BE11:14am

Melrose offers a price ceteris paribus of 405p per GKN share, a 22% premium to yesterday’s close.

BE11:14am

Made up of 20% cash and 80% new Melrose shares.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

As in, 1.49 Melrose shares and 81p cash. Meaning GKN shareholders own 57% of the future group.

BE11:15am

GKN does the "fundamentally undervalues" thing, but also announces its own version of what Melrose would do.

BE11:16am

As in, split auto from aerospace.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Details here https://www.invest...180112075900P78C9/

... and loads of background on the option of a split in the archive, such as here: https://www.ft.com...-8cd4-932067fbf946

BE11:17am

And here: https://www.ft.com...-9ac1-1055824ca907

11:17 am

PM11:18am

BE11:18am

The SAIC Motor one? Hm. I'm still interested that that particular rumour didn't trigger any kind of official response.

FATDAZ morning all
Boncoeur hi daz
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Anyway, let's cut to some sellside. First from the GKN side.

FATDAZ @Boncouer Yes and Retail sales too
FATDAZ @Boncouer Hi
BE11:19am

Oh -- should also note the small warning in GKN's trading update.

BE11:19am

As per Goldman:

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The company confirmed 4Q performance in line with expectations. Management
profit before tax is still expected to be slightly ahead of 2016 levels (£678mn) before the working capital write-offs announced on November 16 associated with the North American Aerospace business. These write-offs are now expected to be near the upper end of the £80-130mn guidance range, and will be included within management profit before tax.

BE11:20am

Goldman's valuation work goes ......

BE11:20am

Our 12m price target of 365p is based on 9.1x 2019E EV/DACF
(the company’s long-run average multiple). This implies a value of 398p per share, before
the impact of any proposed restructuring measures announced today. We then discount
this back 12 months at a 9% WACC to arrive at our target price of 365p. Key downside
risks to our view and price target include: continued pricing pressure in commercial
aerospace and Driveline; continuing execution issues in Aerospace North America;
further AWD costs associated with volume increases; and FX moves (stronger £).

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Which isn't really relevant this morning. More relevant is Sandy Morris at Jefferies.

BE11:21am

We understand the recent management changes, the costly claims and the balance sheet review in Aerospace North America have been unsettling, but none should ostensibly undermine GKN’s market-leading position in Driveline and Powder Metallurgy or prevent the growth in Aerospace inexorably manifesting itself. The key questions in the market’s mind were probably about execution and the tenability of the current Group structure, in our view. GKN has now launched Project Boost, a two-year programme to improve cash and profit with GKN “confident” it will deliver a step change in profit margin and cash generation, with the full run-rate for cash flow achieved during 2020 “through a combination of cost and capital expenditure reduction and pricing discipline”. No mention is made by GKN of any up-front cost or investment being associated with Project Boost. Project Boost also includes rationalisation of non-core product segments. Finally, GKN intends to separate the Aerospace and Automotive businesses, having undertaken an intensive analysis of the economic benefits and costs, including the costs of pensions and tax.

BE11:21am

Sum-of-the-parts (SOTP). On 15 September 2017, we wrote: “For Driveline, we have viewed Autoliv and Borg Warner (BW) as peers. BW’s Bloomberg consensus FY18 PER is 12.1x; Autoliv is now 18x. Our total forecast Driveline + Powder Met FY18 EBIT is £520m which after tax of 24% is EPS of 23p. Assume a PER of 13x = 299p. Our forecast FY18 Aero EBIT is £410m, so EPS of 18p – and if we use Spirt Aero’s FY18 Bberg consensus PER of 14.5x that gives 263p. Total 562p. Actuarial pension deficit after £250m planned payment is @£550m so 32p/share. GKN net debt end FY18 forecast at 26p/share. Total net outcome is 504p”. The major change is that forecast FY18 Aerospace underlying EBIT is now £295m, lower by £115m. That takes 74p off the above SOTP, but one could argue the growth in Aerospace EBIT between FY17 and FY20 has only been pushed out by three years, making it a matter of timing to a degree. Further, end FY18 net debt is now forecast to be around 20p/share higher. Nonetheless, our SOTP should now strictly be around 410p – except that the peer valuations have risen. The Bberg consensus FY18 PER for Spirit Aero is now 16.7x, not 14.5x (this claws back 46p of value), BW is now 13.3x not 12.1x and Autoliv is now 18.9x not 18x.

Waterloo Isn't it Davos weekend. Will Trump win friends or make new enemies?
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Here’s trouble. We venture the debate as to the correct valuation lies between our DCF valuation of 426p and our SOTP of 504p. We know the latter – based on our revised forecasts for FY18 – has ostensibly been undermined to a fair degree, but to what degree depends upon whether the EBIT growth in Aerospace has merely been postponed and the market’s level of confidence in GKN to execute Project Boost. Over some years, we have met with the divisional management and have never had any reason to question its strength other than that by GKN’s own admission “profit margins and cash generation have been below expectations”. Leaving aside any devil in the detail of our SOTP, pensions and tax, this could all come down to how positive an impact the new Chief Executive can make. We maintain our DCF-based PT of 425p.

Mouselet I think there will be an enormous amount of very carefully applied tact

.......... which seems reasonable, really. Now that GKN's tried to head Melrose off at the pass by announcing its own split, it really comes down to which management team investors prefer.

Well .... so every punter in the market has heard talk around Vectura, which is vulnerable for all the obvious reasons. The biggest being constant delays to generic Advair, which seems to have forced the company into more of a partnership model.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

That seems quite unlikely, because what would GSK take from buying out a licence partner rather than just continuing the partnership?

BE11:33am

Here's Citi.

BE11:33am

We see a bid by GSK at such a level as an unlikely use of funds, despite GSK’s incumbent presence in respiratory, with Advair and its newer Ellipta products (Breo/Relvar/Anoro/Incruse). GSK currently pays Vectura a low single-digit
royalty on the Ellipta products, capped at £9m per annum, as part of the legacy Skyepharma business. In addition, GSK formerly paid a low single-digit royalty to Vectura’s side of the business which was capped at £13m per annum.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

GSK ceased to pay this in July 2016, citing that the associated IP had expired. Vectura has disputed that the IP expires in 2021 and there is a court hearing in the US in December 2018. We understand from Vectura management that, should Vectura prevail, any potential damages will not be capped at £13m per year, but will be a low single-digit percentage of Ellipta sales (consensus forecast for 2017 is £1.5bn). The other nuance to consider is that Vectura is entitled to 15% royalty on Hikma’s generic version of GSK’s Advair. We expect a resolution to the dispute with the FDA in 1Q18 regarding this product, but our expectation is that the company (Hikma) will have to re-run a clinical efficacy study, meaning a delay until at least 2019.

Boncoeur EURUSD thru 1.2
BE11:35am

Seems more likely to me that, if anyone ends up bidding for Vectura, it'd be one of the generic types. But with the US generic market in a hell of a state and showing no signs of improvement, the timing there is a bit tricky.

wayneJ @Pharma - there is bucketing of laws, rules, regulations in this country and general confusion how they are formed. There are many rules and regulations which can be set by ministers without reverting to Parliament (or at least the details). The issue is actually identifying which of those have been 'outsourced' to the EU and whether we actually disagree with them (eg clean beaches, clean drinking water?). Also the obvious solution was the 'Sovereignty Bill' which would simply have affirmed / confirmed that Parliament was supreme and could override any EU regulation or law should it please - and was compatible with the EU (? Lisbon treaty) re subsidiarisation (sorry can't remember the exact phrase)

PM11:48am

Symphony's scientists have found a way to upgrade the plastic so that it will convert itself into biodegradable materials at the end of its useful life and will be recycled back into nature like a leaf or a piece of seaweed. It is crucial to understand that it does not just fall into fragments, but the molecular structure is dismantled so that it is no longer a plastic.

We believe that the -9% year to date share price correction creates an attractive entry point in SSP shares, now trading on 25.6x CY19e P/E and 4.9% FCF yield. BE11:56am

Our forecasts were too low: upgrading FY21e margins to 7.6%. Since initiating on SSP in 2014 we had viewed the margin potential in the context of the 4-year “plan” communicated at the time of the IPO, and modeled flat margins after FY18e. The strong delivery, supportive FY18e guidance, and recent management comments suggest that there is instead potential for continued efficiencies. We estimate that the FY17 margin of 6.8% could have reached 7.4% adjusted for investments in infrastructure and start -up costs. We upgrade our FY21e margin from 7.2% to 7.6%. This brings a +70p upgrade to our price target.

BE11:57am

Valuing the backlog. We estimate that SSP has been awarded new contracts worth £314m in annualized revenue between 2015 and 2017, representing c. 13% of the 2017 revenue base. We are still reluctant to model those in our explicit FY18e-FY21e forecasts given the lumpy nature of openings and closures. But we believe the strong delivery in new business in H217, at +7.9%, proves that this backlog will eventually translate 1 for 1 into revenue. We now assume 6.0% medium-term growth beyond our explicit forecasts in our DCF model (previously 4.5%), and 3.0% long-term growth (previously 2.0%). This brings a +130p upgrade to our price target.
